title: Shocking footage shows sexual harassment suffered by women in Britain EVERY DAY
text:
TV Shocking footage shows sexual harassment suffered by women in Britain EVERY DAY Half of the women in the UK say they have been sexually harassed in public and an ITV show went undercover to look at the extent of the problem Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get celebs   Thank you for subscribing!   
Footage filmed undercover in London shows how women are being routinely harassed by men in Britain every day. 
ITV 's Tonight programme hired writer Naomi Hefter to walk around London for filming, with shocking results as she was verbally harassed a number of times. 
She told how she has suffered from sexual harassment in the past which has even led to men following her while walking home. 
She says: “My own personal experience, I must’ve been 15 or 16 coming home from college and a guy on a bike stopped and touched me and from then to now it could be as little as a beep in a car to men even following me. I’ve had walking home, people coming up behind me.” 
During filming, one man was caught taking photographs of her from behind in the street but refused to apologise when he was confronted and insisted what he was doing was fine. A man follows Naomi along the street snapping her as she films (Photo: ITV) 
Naomi said: “I just sensed something and I heard clicking as well, turned round and he’s literally below me, click click click click. I’ve had it before on the tube where people are slyly taking photos, just unbelievable. Read More Uber launches 'urgent investigation' into allegations of sexual harassment at the company 
“The idea of how he thought it was okay to do that, the entitlement, is just beyond belief. I felt quite violated by it.” 
Watching the footage, former Nottinghamshire Police chief constable Sue Fish says: “Without doubt, in this circumstance it’s sexual harassment. So we would record them as a crime and additionally as a hate crime. 
"Any other force has a duty to that victim to record them as a crime. So it doesn’t matter whether they’re in London, whether they’re in Newcastle, whether they’re in Birmingham, or Nottingham, or any other city for that matter, they should be reporting them to their local police for them to take action. It’s completely unacceptable.” He seems to be shooting from the hip and taking pictures of her from behind (Photo: ITV) 
ITV's Tonight programme also polled 2,000 women aged between 18 and 34 and found half of the women in Britain say they have been sexually harassed in public. 
A total of 29 per cent of those surveyed had been verbally sexually harassed in the street, while 18 per cent say they had been both physically and verbally harassed. 
It also found that 56 per cent of respondents say they had been physically or verbally sexually harassed - or both - by a stranger in a bar or club, but only 10 per cent say they had made a complaint about the behaviour. Naomi turns as she hears the man's camera clicking (Photo: ITV) 
The programme asked all UK police forces using Freedom of Information legislation how many alleged sexual offences had been reported to them on school premises in the past three years. 
Those forces who responded indicated there had been more than 7,000 alleged offences reported in that time, including more than 700 alleged rapes . 
Around a third of incidents were between children themselves.

It’s completely unacceptable.” 
Rachel Krys of the End Violence Against Women Coalition says: “Sexual harassment is not a come on, it’s not a precursor to a relationship, it’s about men controlling what women do and wanting to stop women being free to walk down the streets, to just take the space that they’re entitled to. "It’s about saying, ‘I’m in control of this space, I’m in control of you, I have a right to comment on your body, to comment on what you’re wearing.’ And so it’s a really important issue that we need to challenge, and it’s the men we need to challenge, and we need to stop the perpetrators harassing women in the street.”
